In one unforgettable image, Valluvar paints a picture of a woman marking each day her husband is away, scratching lines on the wall to keep count (Kural 1261). Love was not a fleeting romance â€” it was record-keeping.Occupations of the time unfold too â€” farmers, weavers, palanquin bearers, carpenters, hunters, soldiers, barbers, potters, religious pundits, and goldsmiths. Farmers drew from wells (Kural 396) and spring waters (Kural 1161). â€œIf the farmer tills properly,â€ Valluvar wrote in Kural 1037, â€œno manure is needed.â€ A principle that would echo well with modern soil scientistsâ€™ warning against nutrient run-off and pollution.A few months ago, I was running late and requested my daughter to heat the sambar I had made. If you use them for other foods, the next time you boil milk, it may curdle.â€She looked at me suspiciously. â€œIs this a new house rule?â€â€œItâ€™s a rule, yes,â€ I said, switching off the stove and quickly transferring the sambar. â€œBut itâ€™s not new. Itâ€™s been followed in households like ours for over 2,000 years.She raised an eyebrow. â€œBecause thereâ€™s evidence â€” not archaeological, but literary,â€ I said. In, Valluvar uses the metaphor of pure milk turning bad because of an unclean vessel to speak of wealth in the hands of the undeserving. Valluvar even uses the termfor vessels exclusively used only for milk.â€She paused, then said, â€œSometimes you are proud because you started something new. But sometimes you're proud because you are part of a continuum â€” something thatâ€™s been going on for centuries.â€I couldnâ€™t agree more. Thatâ€™s exactly why the images from Keeladi gave me goosebumps. It was a proud, humbling reminder: We are not the beginning of anything. We are a single link in a chain forged long before usâ€”and if we are mindful, a link that will hold firm for generations to come.
